Fig. 1 Reported dehydration pathways from various BDOs: (A) from 1,3-BDO to BD, (B) from 2,3-BDO to BD, and (C) from 1,4-BDO to BD. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Plausible reaction route from 1,4-BDO to GBL. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Effect of contact time (W/F 1,4-BDO) on dehydration of 1,4-BDO at 633 K over CeO2 catalysts calcined at different temperatures. Reaction conditions: CeO2 100 mg; feed rate of 1,4-BDO 0.12–1.2 mL h−1; W/F 1,4-BDO = 7.4–74 g h mol−1; N2 flow rate 30 mL min−1; reaction temperature 633 K. Conversion, carbon balance (C.B.), and selectivity are the values averaged in the TOS range of 30–120 min. The detailed data are summarized in Table S7. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 1,4-BDO dehydration at 663 K over CeO2 catalyst calcined at 673 K as a function of time on stream. Reaction conditions: CeO2 (calcined at 673 K) 100 mg; feed rate of 1,4-BDO 0.12 mL h−1; W/F 1,4-BDO = 74 g h mol−1; N2 flow rate 30 mL min−1; reaction temperature 663 K. The detailed data are summarized in Table S10. Abbreviations in the figure: BD = 1,3-butadiene; THF = tetrahydrofuran; 4-HN = 4-heptanone; 2-PN = 2-pentanone. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 TG-DTA profiles for the CeO2 catalyst after the reaction for (A) 90 min, (B) 120 min, (C) 240 min. Reaction conditions: CeO2 calcined at 673 K 100 mg; feed rate of 1,4-BDO 0.12 mL h−1; W/F 1,4-BDO = 74 g h mol−1; N2 flow rate 30 mL min−1; reaction temperature 663 K. Analysis conditions: sample ca. 10 mg; air flow 30 mL min−1; ramp rate 10 K min−1. The detailed quantification data are available in Table S11. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Dehydration of 3B1OL at different contact times (W/F 3B1OL) over CeO2 catalysts calcined at different temperatures. Reaction conditions: CeO2 100 mg; feed rate of 3B1OL 0.30–2.4 mL h−1; W/F 1,4-BDO = 0.36–29 g h mol−1; N2 flow rate 30 mL min−1; reaction temperature 633 K. Conversion, carbon balance (C.B.), and selectivity are the values averaged in the TOS range of 30–120 min. The reactions marked with an asterisk employed 10 mg of CeO2. The detailed data are summarized in Table S12. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Plausible reaction network of 1,4-BDO transformation. The compounds in parentheses are possible intermediates and were not detected in this work. Department of Applied Chemistry, School of Engineering, Tohoku University 6-6-07 Aoba, Aramaki, Aoba-ku Sendai Miyagi 980-8579 Japan Dehydration of biomass-derived 1,4-butanediol (1,4-BDO) is an attractive approach to synthesizing 1,3-butadiene (BD), which is a useful monomer for various polymers and currently produced via naphtha cracking. Cerium oxide (CeO2) with weak acid-base bifunctionality promoted the dehydration of 1,4-BDO to BD in 66% yield with 80% selectivity under the optimized conditions. The selectivity given by the CeO2 catalyst was influenced by the calcination temperatures, since the acid-base bifunctionality and reducibility of CeO2, which were examined temperature-programmed analyses, were altered. In stark contrast, the catalysts with strong acid sites exemplified by SiO2-Al2O3 and H-type mordenite (H-MOR) were inappropriate for this reaction since they produced tetrahydrofuran as a major product. The control experiments using a set of substrates suggested that 3-butene-1-ol was the main intermediate in the 1,4-BDO-to-BD dehydration, and its isomer of 2-butene-1-ol was also involved in the reaction but rather triggered the undesired side reactions to form butyraldehyde and ketones. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Biomass Catalytic dehydration 1,3-Butadiene 1,4-Butanediol Cerium oxide Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Biomass is the only renewable carbon source and its chemical transformation into platform chemicals as well as value-added chemicals has been investigated widely [1–6]. Due to the presence of excessive oxygen atoms in biomass-derived molecules, the complete/partial removal of oxygen-containing functionalities is required. Various catalytic approaches have been developed for this objective, e.g., hydrodeoxygenation (DODH) [7–12] and dehydration [12–17]. In the latter type of reaction, polyols are typical substrates since they are derivatized easily from abundant sugar compounds. 1,4-Butanediol (1,4-BDO) is one of such polyols and can be synthesized by sugar fermentation [18,19] and the transformation of biomass-derived succinic acid [20–23], 1,4-anhydroerythritol [24–26], and erythritol [27–29]. For valorization of 1,4-BDO, catalytic dehydrocyclization of 1,4-BDO to yield γ-butyrolactone (GBL), which has been recognized as an important biomass-derived platform to produce value-added chemicals, has been investigated intensively [30–32]. The dehydration of 1,4-BDO is also an attractive approach, since this reaction provides tetrahydrofuran (THF), which is used as a solvent and precursor to polymers, and 1,3-butadiene (BD), as seen in Fig. 1. BD is an important monomer for massively used synthetic rubbers and polymers [33–36] and currently produced as a byproduct of naphtha cracking operated in ethylene plants [37–39]. The shale gas boom has boosted the alteration of raw material for ethylene production from naphtha to ethane [40,41], from the latter of which BD cannot be synthesized directly. Thus, the development of means of producing BD from other resources such as biomass is highly desired. In addition to the dehydration of butanediols (BDOs) including 1,4-BDO as described above, the production of BD from ethanol is also possible [35,36]. The two-stage reactor with Ag/SiO2 and HfO2/SiO2 catalysts provided 63% selectivity to BD with 99% ethanol conversion [42]. Yet, as found in the generally accepted reaction pathway, the conversion of ethanol to BD consists of five steps, making the further improvement of its efficiency difficult. Two-step deoxydehydration (DODH) of erythritol, which is a C4 sugar alcohol produced via fermentation [43], is another possible synthetic route for BD [44–50], yet the issue of requirement of precious metal(s) for DODH catalysts still needs to be considered. In this context, there is enough room for improvement in the dehydration of 1,4-BDO to BD, which consists of two steps and is thus simpler than the conversion of ethanol to BD. As described above, the dehydration of 1,4-BDO proceeds toward two different routes (i.e., dehydrative cyclization to THF and two-step dehydration to BD, Fig. 1), indicating the importance of precise control of surface properties of catalysts and well-understanding of reaction. The dehydration of 1,3-BDO, which is an isomer of 1,4-BDO and can be synthesized by the C–O hydrogenolysis of 1,4-anhydroerythritol [51], is easier than that of 1,4-BDO due to the structure of 1,3-BDO. For the 1,3-BDO dehydration, typical heterogeneous acid catalysts are applicable; for example, BD has been produced in up to 55% yield over H-ZSM-5 catalyst thus far [52]. Over the more appropriate catalyst of Y2Zr2O7, as high as 96% yield of BD was achieved from 1,3-BDO [53]. In contrast, typical acid catalysts such as zeolites and SiO2-Al2O3 suffer from side reactions in the dehydration of 2,3-BDO and 1,4-BDO. In the case of 2,3-BDO, which can be synthesized by the C–O hydrogenolysis of erythritol [54,55], its dehydration over strong-acid catalysts such as H-ZSM-5 typically provides an enol intermediate, followed by the keto-enol tautomerization to produce 2-butanone as a major product [56]. Sc2O3 catalyst has been reported to produce BD in up to 88% yield from 2,3-BDO, and its acid-base bifunctionality with oxygen defect sites and appropriate distance of metal centers (i.e., Sc–Sc) is crucial for such outstanding catalytic performance [57]. The production of 3-buten-2-ol from 2,3-BDO was also reported over ZrO2 catalyst [58]. Similar to the dehydration of 2,3-BDO, strong-acid catalysts such as SiO2-Al2O3 and zeolites were not effective for the BD production from 1,4-BDO and rather produced THF as a dominant product [59,60]. The high-yielding production of BD (94%) from 1,4-BDO was achieved using HBr as a catalyst (Table S1) [61], but such homogeneous catalysts are difficult to be separated from products and applied to continuous flow reactions. Therefore, the development of heterogeneous catalysts is desirable. Sato et al. demonstrated Yb2O3 to exhibit excellent catalytic performance for the dehydration of 1,4-BDO to BD and produce 97% yield of BD under the optimized conditions (entries 7 and 11, Table S2) [62,63]. The triad consisting of two metal centers (Yb3+) as Lewis acid sites and one lattice oxygen (O2-) as Lewis base site was invoked as active sites for the dehydration of 1,4-BDO. In the same reports, other rare-earth metal oxides such as Er2O3, Dy2O3, Sm2O3, and CeO2 were also found as promising catalysts; yet, these oxides were tested under the limited reaction conditions. We have previously employed a commercially available CeO2 catalyst that possesses relatively high specific surface area for a variety of reactions, and its acid-base bifunctionality and also defect sites can be tuned upon its calcination at different temperatures [64–71]. Likewise, due to such unique surface properties as well as redox properties, CeO2 itself, CeO2-containing mixed oxides, and CeO2-supported metal (and/or metal oxide) nanoparticles have been developed as efficient catalysts for various biomass valorization, e.g., gasification of cedar wood to syngas [72,73], ketonization of heptanal to 7-tridecanone [74], hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol to phenol [75,76], and DODH of vicinal diols to olefins [50,77]. Therefore, in this work, we examined the activity of CeO2 catalysts calcined at different temperatures for the dehydration of 1,4-BDO with a fixed-bed flow reactor under various reaction conditions, e.g., reaction temperature and contact time. The reaction network starting from 1,4-BDO over CeO2 was proposed on the basis of various control reactions where possible intermediates, 3-buten-1-ol (3B1OL) and 2-buten-1-ol (2B1OL) were employed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts and reagents SiO2-Al2O3 (6.5 mol% aluminum content, grade 135), H-mordenite (H-MOR, Si/Al molar ratio = 7.5, HSZ-620HOA), Yb2O3, MgO (500 A) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, Tosoh, Kanto Chemical, Ube Material Industries, respectively. CeO2 (HS grade) and ZrO2 (RC-100) were purchased from Daiichi Kigenso Kagaku Kogyo. These materials were used after calcination in air in an electric furnace for 3 h at designated temperatures (773 K for SiO2-Al2O3 and H-MOR; 873 K for Yb2O3, MgO, and ZrO2; 673–1273 K for CeO2). 1,4-BDO, 3-buten-1-ol (3B1OL), 2-buten-1-ol (2B1OL; mixture of cis- and trans-isomers with their molar ratio of 1/24), and n-pentane were purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry. 1-Propanol and 1-octanol were purchased from FUJIFILM Wako Chemicals. 2.2 Catalytic reaction All catalytic reactions in this study were conducted using a fixed-bed down-flow quartz tubular reactor (Fig. S1). Catalyst powder was pressurized to be pelletized and then crushed slightly, and the resulting granulated sample was classified on a sieve to obtain the specific size of granules (180–250 µm in diameter, unless otherwise specified). The sieved sample was packed into a quartz tube (ϕ6 mm, length 240 mm) and fixed by sandwiching the catalyst with ca. 1 cm of quartz wool. In the case of the granulated samples with 180–250 µm in diameter, the height of the catalyst bed was approximately 15 mm (SiO2-Al2O3 and H-MOR) or 5 mm (the other catalysts). The quartz tube was placed in an tubular electric furnace (ϕ4 cm, length 15 cm) and then heated at the designated reaction temperature, which was monitored with a thermocouple that was inserted from the top of the quartz tube. Then, a liquid reactant (1,4-BDO, 3B1OL, or 2B1OL) was fed through the reactor at the designated flow rate using a syringe pump (BS-MD1001, AS ONE), together with a N2 flow of 30 mL min−1. The contact time, W/F substrate (unit: g h mol−1), was defined as the division of catalyst weight (W (g)) by flow rate of substrate (F substrate (mol h−1)). In this study, the time when the fed solution reached the upper quartz bed was defined as the time on stream (TOS) of 0 h. We should note that since several minutes were always necessary to gain a steady flow, carbon balance and conversion were not stable within the TOS of 20 min (Table S3). The outlet liquid was collected in 1-propanol and also the outlet gas was collected in a gas bag. Liquid products were analyzed by a gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector (GC-FID; Shimadzu, GC-2014) and a TC-WAX capillary column (GL Sciences, ϕ0.25 mm, 30 m, film thickness 0.25 µm). For this analysis, 1-octanol was used as an internal standard. Gaseous products were quantified by a GC equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (GC-TCD; Shimadzu, GC-8A) and VZ-7 packed column (GL Sciences, mesh 60/80, length 6 m, inner diameter 3 mm). In this case, n-pentane was used as an internal standard. The conversion, selectivity, and carbon balance were calculated on the carbon-basis, as the equations shown below. The carbon balance sometimes became below 90%, which may be due to the formation of products that could not be detected by GCs. Conversion ( % ) = Σ Mole of carbon atoms in product mol Σ Mole of carbon atoms in product and unreacted substrate mol × 100 Selectivity to product ( % ) = Mole of carbon atoms in product ( mol ) Σ Mole of carbon atoms in product mol × 100 Carbon balance ( % ) = Mole of carbon atoms in unreacted substrate ( mol ) + Σ Mole of carbon atoms in product mol Mole of carbon atoms in charged substrate ( mol ) × 100 Yield of product ( % ) = Conversion ( % ) 100 × Selectivity to product ( % ) 100 × Carbon balance ( % ) 100 × 100 2.3 Characterization The specific surface area of catalysts except for H-MOR was examined by N2 physisorption measurement at 77 K (Micromeritics, Gemini VII) and the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, for which the data points in the p/p 0 range from 0.05 to 0.30 in the adsorption isotherm were employed. The specific surface area of H-MOR was reported by the supplier (400 m2 g−1) [78]. The crystal structure was examined by X-ray diffraction measurement (XRD; MiniFlex600, Rigaku, Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 40 mA)). The acid and base sites were quantified by temperature-programed desorption using NH3 and CO2 (NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD; MicrotracMRB, BELCAT II, equipped with a quadrupole mass spectrometer (Q-MS; MicrotracMRB, BELMASS) and TCD). Prior to each analysis, 0.5–5.0 g of the sample was pretreated in a He flow (30 mL min−1) at 673 K for 1 h, exposed to 5.0 vol% NH3/He (30 mL min−1) at 373 K for 30 min, and further treated in a He flow (30 mL min−1) for 15 min. For CO2-TPD measurement, instead of NH3/He, 9.9 vol% CO2/He (30 mL min−1) was flowed at the same temperature. During the measurement, the temperature increased from 373 K to 1273 K at a ramp rate of 10 K min−1 with a He flow (30 mL min−1). Thermogravimetry and differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) was conducted with Rigaku Thermo Plus EVOII, where ca. 10 mg of sample was thermally treated in an air flow (30 mL min−1) with a ramp rate of 10 K min−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst screening Catalyst screening was initially conducted to elucidate the performance of various metal oxides for the 1,4-BDO dehydration at the W/F 1,4-BDO of 7.4 g h mol−1 ( Table 1 and S4). Without catalyst, 1,4-BDO was not converted at all at the reaction temperature of 633 K (entry 1). The amphoteric oxides, ZrO2, CeO2, and Yb2O3, yielded 3B1OL as a major product along with BD, 2B1OL, and THF (entries 4, 6, and 7). Since both 3B1OL and 2B1OL are the intermediates in the 1,4-BDO dehydration to BD, these catalysts have a potential to exhibit good yield and selectivity of BD under optimum conditions. Among these three amphoteric oxides, CeO2 showed the highest selectivity to 3B1OL, 2B1OL, and BD with the lowest selectivity to THF. When ZrO2 was compared with CeO2 at the same conversion level by reducing its loading amount from 100 mg to 25 mg, the cyclization to THF still proceeded in 35% selectivity (entry 5). We also note that although Yb2O3 with the specific surface area of 28.8 m2 g−1 was previously reported to produce BD in up to 96% yield with 100% conversion of 1,4-BDO at 633 K at the W/F 1,4-BDO of 202 g h mol−1 [62], Yb2O3 tested in this study converted only 5.5% of 1,4-BDO possibly due to its low specific surface area of 2.2 m2 g−1. In the cases of acid catalysts (i.e., SiO2-Al2O3 and H-MOR), THF was a main product with almost no formation of other products (entries 2 and 3). Note that in these cases, the reaction temperature was lowered to 473 K to reduce the conversion rate and also suppress the severe coke formation. THF was previously reported to undergo ring-opening dehydration to form BD over phosphorus-containing zeotypes [79], but such reaction route was unlikely to be involved in our current investigation. MgO showed almost no catalytic performance (entry 8), indicating that a base oxide is not suitable for this reaction. Altogether, CeO2 was selected as the best catalyst and further investigated in the following sections. To investigate the requirement of catalytic properties for the 1,4-BDO dehydration, the acid and base properties of four catalysts, SiO2-Al2O3, ZrO2, CeO2, and MgO, were analyzed by NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD, as shown in Fig. S2 and Table S5. Note that the surface nature of CeO2 calcined at 873 K was re-examined based on our previously reported TPD profiles [71]. The almost inactive oxide, MgO, contained 1.1 μmol m−2 of base sites, while the amount of acid sites was negligible, indicating that a metal oxide without acid sites is not suitable for this reaction. ZrO2 and CeO2, both of which promoted the 1,4-BDO dehydration (vide supra), possessed acid and base sites. ZrO2 had a larger number of acid sites with weak and medium strength, compared to CeO2, because ZrO2 provided the desorption peak in the temperature range of 673–973 K, which was not found clearly for CeO2. Given that ZrO2 exhibited the higher selectivity to THF than CeO2, too much such acid sites may trigger the undesired cyclization of 1,4-BDO to THF. Likewise, SiO2-Al2O3, which produced THF with > 99% selectivity (Table 1), possessed a large number of weak, medium, and strong acid sites. Therefore, the surface with weak acid sites while without moderate or strong acid sites is suggested to be suitable for the selective 1,4-BDO dehydration toward BD. 3.2 Effects of calcination temperature on catalytic performance and surface properties of CeO2 Calcination temperature is well-known to impact on surface properties and catalytic performance of metal oxides [64–66,71,80–82], motivating us to investigate the effects of calcination temperature. Table 2 and S6 show the results of the 1,4-BDO dehydration over the CeO2 catalyst calcined at 673, 873, 1073, and 1273 K. Due to the low specific surface area of CeO2 calcined at 1073 and 1273 K, a large amount of catalyst was employed to fairly compare the product selectivity at the same conversion level. In all cases, 3B1OL was yielded as a major product. The selectivity to 3B1OL and 2B1OL increased gradually from 68% to 76% and 2.8–7.3%, respectively, upon an increase in the calcination temperature. Instead, the selectivity to THF and GBL decreased from 12% to 3.5% and 8.3–4.7%. This trend indicated that the sites that cause the undesired reactions were eliminated by the high-temperature calcination. Yet, in the case of the calcination temperature of 1273 K, the three-fold larger amount of this catalyst was required to achieve the same conversion level as the CeO2 catalysts calcined at the other temperatures due to its low specific surface area. In this context, we decided to employ and compare the CeO2 catalysts calcined at 673, 873, and 1073 K in the following reaction tests. Prior to the further investigation of reaction parameters, we compared the current reaction results with the acid and base properties of the calcined CeO2 specimens re-examined on the basis of our previous TPD data [71] ( Table 3 and Fig. S3). The amount of acid/base sites decreased with an increase of calcination temperatures; this trend is connected to the higher crystallinity (Fig. S4) and lower specific surface area (Table 3) of CeO2 calcined at higher temperatures. The CeO2 samples calcined at 673 K and 873 K provided the desorption peak in the temperature range of 673–1173 K in NH3-TPD, indicating the presence of moderate and strong acid sites. As discussed above, such moderate/strong acid sites are likely to be responsible for the production of THF. Therefore, the decreasing trend for the THF selectivity upon an increase in the calcination temperature can be explained by the amount of moderate/strong acid sites on the CeO2 surface. Our previous data based on the H2-TPR measurements [70] provided another insight on the surface property of CeO2 catalysts calcined at different temperatures, i.e., reduction property. Fig. S5 shows the H2-TPR profiles. The reduction peak in the temperature range of 562–860 K, which is assignable to the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ [83], became clearly smaller as the calcination temperature of CeO2 increased. The H2 consumption amount decreased from 0.47 mmol g−1 to 0.14 mmol g−1 with an increase in the calcination temperature from 673 K to 1073 K (Table 3). As discussed previously in our report [70] and also similar to the acid/base sites described above, the surface area of CeO2 decides the amount of mobile oxygen atoms since the H2 consumption amounts on the basis of specific surface area were constant regardless of the calcination temperature. Given that the CeO2 catalysts calcined at lower temperatures were apt to exhibit higher GBL selectivity (Table 2) and GBL is formed from 1,4-BDO via a two-step dehydrogenation reaction ( Fig. 2), the reactive oxygen species in the CeO2 lattice could cause the undesired side reaction to GBL. Yet, as shown in the next section, the side reactions to carbonyl compounds, namely BuAld, affected the selectivity to BD much more than that to GBL. 3.3 Optimization of reaction conditions: contact time and temperature We investigated the effects of reaction conditions such as contact time (W/F 1,4-BDO) and temperature for the CeO2 catalysts calcined at 673 K, 873 K, and 1073 K. Fig. 3 and Table S7 represent the dependence of reaction results on W/F 1,4-BDO at 633 K. All the catalysts tested here exhibited the comparative 1,4-BDO conversion at each W/F 1,4-BDO, and the 1,4-BDO conversion increased upon an increase of the W/F 1,4-BDO. The low W/F 1,4-BDO of 7.4 g h mol−1 provided 3B1OL mainly, while its selectivity gradually decreased with an increase of the W/F 1,4-BDO and BD became a major product at the W/F 1,4-BDO of 74 g h mol−1. Therefore, the two-step dehydration necessitates high W/F 1,4-BDO. The order of the BD selectivity achieved by the three CeO2 catalysts agreed well with that of the acid-site content (Table 3); this consistency clearly indicated the requirement of acid sites for the two-step dehydration from 1,4-BDO to BD. Besides, upon the decrease in the 3B1OL selectivity at the higher W/F 1,4-BDO, the selectivity to carbonyl compounds (i.e., butyraldehyde (BuAld), 2-pentanone (2-PN), and 4-heptanone (4-HN)) gradually increased. This trend indicated that these carbonyl compounds were formed from 3B1OL and/or related compound(s), not directly from 1,4-BDO. Meanwhile, the selectivity to 2B1OL was almost constant regardless of the catalysts or W/F 1,4-BDO. This behavior indicates two possible situations: the formation and consumption of 2B1OL is comparable and/or the consumption of 2B1OL is slow. This point is further investigated and discussed later (see Section 3.5). The reaction temperature was then varied from 603 K to 663 K at the W/F 1,4-BDO of 74 g h mol−1 with the CeO2 catalysts calcined at 673 K, 873 K, and 1073 K ( Table 4 and S8). All the CeO2 catalysts produced 3B1OL as a major product (67–70% selectivity) at 603 K with the relatively high conversion of 1,4-BDO (66–84%). At the higher reaction temperatures of 633 K and 663 K, BD was the dominant product (47–80% selectivity) with almost complete conversion of 1,4-BDO. The highest yield of BD achieved in this study was 66% when the reaction was operated at 663 K with the CeO2 catalyst calcined at 673 K. For any CeO2 catalysts, the comparison of the reaction data obtained at 633 K and 663 K implied that the two ketone compounds, 2-PN and 4-HN, were produced from BuAld. Indeed, the control experiments using BuAld as a substrate provided the high selectivity to ketones (Table S9). Altogether, the CeO2 catalyst dehydrated 1,4-BDO into BD in 66% yield with 80% selectivity under the optimum reaction conditions. 3.4 1,4-BDO dehydration over CeO2 catalyst as a function of time on stream The stability of the CeO2 catalyst calcined at 673 K was examined under the optimum reaction conditions. Fig. 4 and Table S10 represent the data for the 1,4-BDO dehydration over this catalyst for TOS of 240 min. At the beginning of this operation, the BD selectivity slightly decreased along with the increase of 2-PN and 4-HN. Yet, after the TOS of 60 min, the BD conversion and selectivity to each product were kept unchanged. Therefore, the CeO2 catalyst is stable in the 1,4-BDO dehydration under the current conditions. According to previously reported study on the 1,4-BDO dehydration, acid catalysts typically suffer from severe surface deposition of organic and even carbonaceous species to be deactivated and thus require calcination to remove such species [62,84]. This fact with the reaction data above motivated us to investigate the quantity of surface-deposited species by TG-DTA. Fig. 5 shows the TG-DTA profiles for the CeO2 catalyst after the 1,4-BDO dehydration for 90 min, 180 min, and 240 min. The observation of a weight loss with an exothermic peak in each profile indicated the deposition of organic species on the CeO2 surface, and for example, the quantity of deposited organic species was calculated to be 5.4 mg per 100 mg of the catalyst after the reaction for 90 min (Table S11). Interestingly, the amount of surface-deposited species was unchanged even after the reaction operation for 240 min. These data thus indicate that organic species were formed at the beginning of the reaction operation and could cover the catalyst surface partially. However, such surface coverage by organic species does not matter for the CeO2 catalyst, leading to the good stability of the CeO2 catalyst as demonstrated in Fig. 4. 3.5 Dehydration of 3B1OL and 2B1OL over CeO2 catalyst: Investigation of reactivity of each reaction intermediate and proposed reaction network As found in any reaction data in this work and also reported previously, 1,4-BDO is initially dehydrated into 3B1OL. Also, 2B1OL was detected possibly as a result of the isomerization of 3B1OL. Both compounds undergo further dehydration into BD. Herein, to investigate the reactivity of these two compounds, we employed either 3B1OL or 2B1OL as a substrate with the CeO2 catalysts calcined at different temperatures. Fig. 6 and Table S12 show the data of the 3B1OL dehydration at 633 K at the different W/F 3B1OL. The values of the 3B1OL conversion over the CeO2 catalysts were almost the same as each other regardless of the significant difference in their specific surface area (see also Table 3). Although these data implied the limitation of substrate diffusion because of the use of too large granules of CeO2 catalysts (i.e., 180–250 µm in diameter), the diffusion of substrate molecules did not matter in these cases since smaller catalyst granules with 150–180 µm in diameter provided the comparable values of 3B1OL conversion (Table S13). In any cases, the major product was BD, indicating that the dehydration from 3B1OL to BD readily occurred over the CeO2 catalysts. The use of the CeO2 catalyst calcined at 673 K under the optimum conditions provided BD in 66% yield with 86% selectivity. Next to BD, 2B1OL including both trans- and cis-isomers was the second major product at the W/F 3B1OL of 7.2 g h mol−1 or lower, indicating that the isomerization of carbon backbone occurs readily. Meanwhile, the formation of BuAld became prominent at the high W/F 3B1OL of 14 g h mol−1 and 29 g h mol−1. This trend indicates that 2B1OL as well as 3B1OL possibly undergo the isomerization to alter their functionality to produce BuAld. The results of the 2B1OL transformation over the CeO2 catalysts at the W/F 2B1OL of 0.90 g h mol−1 at 633 K, which was the same temperature for the 3B1OL dehydration in Table 4, are shown in Table 5 and S14. The conversion of 2B1OL (14–26%) was comparable to that of 3B1OL (16–20%, Table 4) regardless of the 2.5-fold higher W/F substrate, indicating the poorer reactivity of 2B1OL than that of 3B1OL. The major products detected in the reaction of 2B1OL were BD, 3B1OL, and BuAld. In contrast to previous report investigating the same reaction over SiO2-supported metal-oxide catalysts [85], 3-buten-2-ol was not detected in this study. These data thus demonstrated that 2B1OL undergoes both the dehydration to BD and isomerization to 3B1OL and BuAld. Notably, the selectivity to BuAld was clearly higher than the reactions starting from 3B1OL, indicating that the major source of BuAld is 2B1OL, not 3B1OL. Based on all the discussion above, the plausible reaction network from 1,4-BDO is drawn in Fig. 7. The major production route for BD is two-step dehydration from 1,4-BDO via 3B1OL. This intermediate compound undergoes the reversible isomerization to 2B1OL, which is another intermediate for the BD production. Another type of isomerization of 3B1OL to directly form BuAld may also proceed to some extent, but the major source of BuAld is 2B1OL. BuAld is suggested to further undergo the intermolecular reaction to form ketones, 2-PN and 4-HN. According to previous papers, aldehydes undergo dimerization and oxidation over CeO2-based catalysts [86,87]. Such dimerized compound (in the current case, 2-ethyl-3-hydroxyhexanal) is successively converted to corresponding ketone (4-HN) [86,88]. Carboxylic acids, which are produced via oxidation of aldehydes by lattice oxygen of CeO2 or direct reaction between aldehydes and in-situ generated water [87], are also possible sources of ketones [87,89]. Although we did not detect butyric acid or acetic acid in this study, the observation for the formation of 3-butenyl butyrate and ethanol implied that butyric acid and acetic acid were possibly present but consumed quickly in the reactions. The intermolecular reactions that start from two butyric acid molecules and a butanoic acid molecule and acetic acid molecule provide 4-HN and 2-PN, respectively. In the presence of catalysts with medium or strong acid sites, the dehydrative cyclization of 1,4-BDO proceeds readily to form THF. Although some catalysts were reported to cause the dehydration of THF to BD [79,90,91], but the current CeO2 catalysts do not show activity for such ring-opening reaction. The different type of side reaction via 4-hydroxybutanal also proceeds when catalysts possess oxidative properties. However, at high W/F 1,4-BDO, due to the progress of another type of oxidation reaction of 2B1OL and/or 3B1OL to form BuAld by reactive lattice oxygen of CeO2, the oxidative dehydration to GBL via 4-hydroxybutanal was suppressed (see Figs. 3 and 6). 4 Conclusions The two-step dehydration of 1,4-butanediol (1,4-BDO) into 1,3-butadiene (BD) was promoted by the CeO2 catalyst in a fixed-bed flow reactor. CeO2 exhibited good selectivity to BD and two intermediates, 3-buten-1-ol (3B1OL) and 2-buten-1-ol (2B1OL), and their total selectivity of 77% was achieved at 633 K at the contact time (W/F 1,4-BDO) = 7.4 g h mol−1. The selectivity to tetrahydrofuran (THF) over CeO2 was much lower than those over typical acid catalysts such as SiO2-Al2O3 and H-MOR and also other metal oxides consisting of ZrO2, Yb2O3, and MgO. The acid-base bifunctionality with weak strength of CeO2 was suggested from the temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) measurements to contribute to such high selectivity, and strong acidity found for other catalysts rather catalyzed the dehydrative cyclization into THF. The surface property and catalytic performance of CeO2 were tuned via its calcination at different temperatures. The calcination at the high temperature of 1073 K enabled to eliminate the sites that cause the undesired redox reactions to finally form γ-butyrolactone (GBL) from CeO2, while the selectivity to butyraldehyde (BuAld) became higher than the CeO2 catalyst calcined at lower temperatures. Under the optimized conditions at 663 K at W/F 1,4-BDO = 74 g h mol−1, BD was produced in up to 66% yield with 80% selectivity over the CeO2 catalyst calcined at 673 K. Although a slight amount of organic species was deposited on the CeO2 surface, this catalyst also exhibited a good stability for time on stream (TOS) of 240 min. From the time courses of 1,4-BDO dehydration and also control experiments using 3B1OL and 2B1OL as a substrate, the possible reaction network occurred on the surface of CeO2 catalyst was proposed. Both 3B1OL and 2B1OL were transformed into BD, yet the reactivity of 3B1OL was higher compared to 2B1OL. 2B1OL was the main source for BuAld, and the appropriate catalysts such as CeO2 calcined at lower temperatures were necessary to proceed with the dehydration of 2B1OL to BD with the suppression of the isomerization to BuAld. coredata.dc:description: Dehydration of biomass-derived 1,4-butanediol (1,4-BDO) is an attractive approach to synthesizing 1,3-butadiene (BD), which is a useful monomer for various polymers and currently produced via naphtha cracking. Cerium oxide (CeO2) with weak acid-base bifunctionality promoted the dehydration of 1,4-BDO to BD in 66% yield with 80% selectivity under the optimized conditions. The selectivity given by the CeO2 catalyst was influenced by the calcination temperatures, since the acid-base bifunctionality and reducibility of CeO2, which were examined temperature-programmed analyses, were altered. In stark contrast, the catalysts with strong acid sites exemplified by SiO2-Al2O3 and H-type mordenite (H-MOR) were inappropriate for this reaction since they produced tetrahydrofuran as a major product. The control experiments using a set of substrates suggested that 3-butene-1-ol was the main intermediate in the 1,4-BDO-to-BD dehydration, and its isomer of 2-butene-1-ol was also involved in the reaction but rather triggered the undesired side reactions to form butyraldehyde and ketones.
coredata.dc:title: Selective synthesis of 1,3-butadiene by vapor-phase dehydration of 1,4-butanediol over cerium oxide catalyst
